oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Charlie Walker Interview About 1952 Material
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of Charlie Walker (musician) discussing his 1952 material such as "I'm Looking For You", "Stolen Kisses", "Two Red Lips", and "By Rights You Belong To Me", and "Tell Her Lies And Feed Her Candy" This is side 2 of 2.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Charlie Walker
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) -- Introduction 03/28/1998 Side Two (0:25) Discusses producers' ties to publishing companies and that producers might have an interest in some of the songs presented to artists. Interviewer asks specifically about Paul Cohen and whether he had an interest in what songs were recorded. Charlie Walker responds neutrally and emphasizes that he had a great relationship with the people who he recorded with. (2:14) --- Discusses session for Decca on February 9th, 1956 at Bradley Studios. Mentions Quonset Hut (804 16th Avenue South). "Remembering" written by Cindy Walker, "Stepping Stones" written by Leon Payne, "Stand Still" written by Bob Tanner & TNT Publishing, "Cheaters Never Win" - Acuff/Rose. Charlie Walker mentions that he might have been one of the first guys to record in the Quonset Hut. (5:16) -- Discussion about switch to Mercury/Starday from Decca. Mercury was for the larger artists. (7:56) -- Interviewer mentions that he is skeptical about his 1957 date, but provides information about session in Slim Willet's garage. (9:00) -- Continues discussion about Mercury switch. (10:38) -- Charlie Walker mentions that Slim Willet was a disc jockey in Abilene, TX. They were great friends. (12:06) -- "I'll Never Let It Show" song discussion, Walker mentions that the sax player was Jim Seals. (14:07) -- Charlie Walker mentions that he did the first session in Houston. Slim Willet invited him to Abilene to record. Mentions "Don't Let Stars Get In Your Eyes", with Buck White on piano. (17:30) -- Discussion of his ten children. (20:45) -- Charlie Walker mentions working in Las Vegas, Nevada, after Hank Thompson. Hank Thompson took the gig after Bob Wills left, and then Charlie took over after Hank Thompson.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Walker, Charlie, 1926-2008;
